prior_works.title: Attention Is All You Need
prior_works.authors: Ashish Vaswani, Noam Shazeer, Niki Parmar, Jakob Uszkoreit, Llion Jones, Aidan N. Gomez, Lukasz Kaiser, Illia Polosukhin
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Introduced sinusoidal positional encoding in Transformers, which the present work proves to be a specific solution of a CPG membrane-potential dynamics and uses as the primary baseline that CPG-PE generalizes.

prior_works.title: RoFormer: Enhanced Transformer with Rotary Position Embedding
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Framed position as phase rotations via complex sinusoids, reinforcing an oscillator-based interpretation that directly motivates modeling positional signals with biologically grounded CPG oscillators in SNNs.

prior_works.title: Fourier Features Let Networks Learn High Frequency Functions in Low Dimensional Domains
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Established the effectiveness of multi-frequency sinusoidal coordinate encodings, supporting the paper’s view that PE can be generated by controlled oscillatory dynamics and extended to spike-form signals.

prior_works.title: Sustained oscillations generated by mutually inhibiting neurons with adaptation
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Provides a canonical CPG model whose membrane potential ODEs yield rhythmic outputs; the paper leverages such CPG dynamics to derive spike-form PE and shows sinusoidal PE arises as a special-case solution.

prior_works.title: Central pattern generators for locomotion control in animals and robots: a review
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Synthesizes CPG properties (intrinsic rhythmicity, tunable frequency/phase, robustness) that inform designing a hardware-friendly PE generator for SNNs requiring no rhythmic input.

prior_works.title: Long short-term memory and learning-to-learn in spiking neural networks
prior_works.authors: Guillaume Bellec, Darjan Salaj, Anand Subramoney, Robert Legenstein, Wolfgang Maass
prior_works.role: Problem framing for SNNs on sequential tasks
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Demonstrated SNNs’ capability for long-term temporal credit assignment via intrinsic dynamics, highlighting the need for principled temporal/positional signals that CPG-PE supplies in a spike-native form.

prior_works.title: Surrogate gradient learning in spiking neural networks: Bringing the power of gradient-based optimization to spiking neural networks
prior_works.authors: Emre O. Neftci, Hesham Mostafa, Friedemann Zenke
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Provides the training machinery (surrogate gradients) that enables end-to-end optimization of SNNs incorporating the proposed differentiable CPG-based positional encoding.

synthesis_narrative: The paper’s key contribution—CPG-PE, a spike-native, hardware-friendly positional encoding for SNNs—emerges at the intersection of positional encoding theory, oscillator-based modeling, and practical SNN training for sequential tasks. The modern PE lineage begins with Vaswani et al., whose sinusoidal positional encoding is the de facto baseline; the authors theoretically show this sinusoid is a particular solution to a CPG’s membrane dynamics. RoPE further reframed position as phase rotation, strengthening the oscillator perspective and motivating a phase-controlled PE that aligns naturally with rhythmic neural dynamics. Complementing this, Fourier-feature theory (Tancik et al.) establishes why multi-frequency sinusoids serve as powerful coordinate embeddings, providing a principled basis for composing and tuning oscillatory components. On the biological and mathematical side, Matsuoka’s classic CPG oscillator and Ijspeert’s comprehensive review supply the core principles—intrinsic rhythmicity without rhythmic input, tunable frequency/phase, and robustness—that the paper instantiates in a neuromorphic-compatible PE generator producing spikes. Finally, advances demonstrating SNNs’ aptitude for sequential processing (Bellec et al.) make the case that explicit temporal/positional signals can boost performance, while surrogate-gradient training (Neftci et al.) enables integrating and learning such modules end-to-end. Together, these works converge to a coherent insight: position can be encoded by controlled biological oscillators whose dynamics both subsume sinusoidal PE and yield efficient, spike-form signals suited for SNN hardware and diverse sequential tasks.
